name: 1579_B. Shifting Sort
description:
The new generation external memory contains an array of integers a[1 … n] = [a_1, a_2, …, a_n].

This type of memory does not support changing the value of an arbitrary element. Instead, it allows you to cut out any segment of the given array, cyclically shift (rotate) it by any offset and insert it back into the same place.

Technically, each cyclic shift consists of two consecutive actions: 

  1. You may select arbitrary indices l and r (1 ≤ l < r ≤ n) as the boundaries of the segment. 
  2. Then you replace the segment a[l … r] with it's cyclic shift to the left by an arbitrary offset d. The concept of a cyclic shift can be also explained by following relations: the sequence [1, 4, 1, 3] is a cyclic shift of the sequence [3, 1, 4, 1] to the left by the offset 1 and the sequence [4, 1, 3, 1] is a cyclic shift of the sequence [3, 1, 4, 1] to the left by the offset 2. 



For example, if a = [1, \color{blue}{3, 2, 8}, 5], then choosing l = 2, r = 4 and d = 2 yields a segment a[2 … 4] = [3, 2, 8]. This segment is then shifted by the offset d = 2 to the left, and you get a segment [8, 3, 2] which then takes the place of of the original elements of the segment. In the end you get a = [1, \color{blue}{8, 3, 2}, 5].

Sort the given array a using no more than n cyclic shifts of any of its segments. Note that you don't need to minimize the number of cyclic shifts. Any method that requires n or less cyclic shifts will be accepted.

Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of test cases.

The next 2t lines contain the descriptions of the test cases. 

The first line of each test case description contains an integer n (2 ≤ n ≤ 50) — the length of the array. The second line consists of space-separated elements of the array a_i (-10^9 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^9). Elements of array a may repeat and don't have to be unique.

Output

Print t answers to all input test cases. 

The first line of the answer of each test case should contain an integer k (0 ≤ k ≤ n) — the number of actions to sort the array. The next k lines should contain descriptions of the actions formatted as "l r d" (without quotes) where l and r (1 ≤ l < r ≤ n) are the boundaries of the segment being shifted, while d (1 ≤ d ≤ r - l) is the offset value. Please remember that only the cyclic shifts to the left are considered so the chosen segment will be shifted by the offset d to the to the left.

Note that you are not required to find the minimum number of cyclic shifts needed for sorting. Any sorting method where the number of shifts does not exceed n will be accepted.

If the given array a is already sorted, one of the possible answers is k = 0 and an empty sequence of cyclic shifts.

If there are several possible answers, you may print any of them.

Example

Input


4
2
2 1
3
1 2 1
4
2 4 1 3
5
2 5 1 4 3


Output


1
1 2 1
1
1 3 2
3
2 4 1
2 3 1
1 3 2
4
2 4 2
1 5 3
1 2 1
1 3 1

Note

Explanation of the fourth data set in the example: 

  1. The segment a[2 … 4] is selected and is shifted to the left by 2: [2, \color{blue}{5, 1, 4}, 3] \longrightarrow [2, \color{blue}{4, 5, 1}, 3] 
  2. The segment a[1 … 5] is then selected and is shifted to the left by 3: [\color{blue}{2, 4, 5, 1, 3}] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 3, 2, 4, 5}] 
  3. After that the segment a[1 … 2] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{1, 3}, 2, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{3, 1}, 2, 4, 5] 
  4. And in the end the segment a[1 … 3] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{3, 1, 2}, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 2, 3}, 4, 5]
repair_prompt:
The new generation external memory comprises an array of integers a[1 … n] = [a_1, a_2, …, a_n].

This type of memory does not support changing the value of an arbitrary element. Instead, it allows you to cut out any segment of the given array, cyclically shift (rotate) it by any offset and insert it back into the same place.

Technically, each cyclic shift consists of two consecutive actions: 

  1. You may select arbitrary indices l and r (1 ≤ l < r ≤ n) as the boundaries of the segment. 
  2. Then you substitute the segment a[l … r] with its cyclic shift to the left by an arbitrary offset d. The concept of a cyclic shift can be also explained by following relations: the sequence [1, 4, 1, 3] is a cyclic shift of the sequence [3, 1, 4, 1] to the left by the offset 1 and the sequence [4, 1, 3, 1] is a cyclic shift of the sequence [3, 1, 4, 1] to the left by the offset 2. 

For example, if a = [1, \color{blue}{3, 2, 8}, 5], then choosing l = 2, r = 4 and d = 2 yields a segment a[2 … 4] = [3, 2, 8]. This segment is then shifted by the offset d = 2 to the left, and you get a segment [8, 3, 2] which then takes the place of of the original elements of the segment. In the end you get a = [1, \color{blue}{8, 3, 2}, 5].

Arrange the given array a in order using no more than n cyclic shifts of any of its parts. Note that you don't need to minimize the number of cyclic shifts. Any method that requires n or less cyclic shifts will be accepted.

Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of test cases.

The next 2t lines contain the descriptions of the test cases. 

The first line of each test case description contains an integer n (2 ≤ n ≤ 50) — the length of the array. The second line consists of space-separated elements of the array a_i (-10^9 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^9). Elements of array a may repeat and don't have to be unique.

Output

Print t answers to all input test cases. 

The first line of the answer of each test case should contain an integer k (0 ≤ k ≤ n) — the number of actions to sort the array. The next k lines should contain descriptions of the actions formatted as "l r d" (without quotes) where l and r (1 ≤ l < r ≤ n) are the boundaries of the segment being shifted, while d (1 ≤ d ≤ r - l) is the offset value. Please remember that only the cyclic shifts to the left are considered so the chosen segment will be shifted by the offset d to the to the left.

Note that you are not required to find the minimum number of cyclic shifts needed for sorting. Any sorting method where the number of shifts does not exceed n will be accepted.

If the given array a is already sorted, one of the possible answers is k = 0 and an empty sequence of cyclic shifts.

If there are several possible answers, you may print any of them.

Example

Input


4
2
2 1
3
1 2 1
4
2 4 1 3
5
2 5 1 4 3


Output


1
1 2 1
1
1 3 2
3
2 4 1
2 3 1
1 3 2
4
2 4 2
1 5 3
1 2 1
1 3 1

Note

Explanation of the fourth data set in the example: 

  1. The segment a[2 … 4] is selected and is shifted to the left by 2: [2, \color{blue}{5, 1, 4}, 3] \longrightarrow [2, \color{blue}{4, 5, 1}, 3] 
  2. The segment a[1 … 5] is then selected and is shifted to the left by 3: [\color{blue}{2, 4, 5, 1, 3}] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 3, 2, 4, 5}] 
  3. After that the segment a[1 … 2] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{1, 3}, 2, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{3, 1}, 2, 4, 5] 
  4. And in the end the segment a[1 … 3] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{3, 1, 2}, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 2, 3}, 4, 5] 

-------
Important Note: You must follow the input output format. Input must be taken from standard input and output must be given to standard output. The code will be tested against multiple test cases and all the test cases must be passed.
completion:
def cyclic_shift_sort(t, test_cases):
    results = []
    
    for i in range(t):
        n, array = test_cases[i]
        sorted_array = sorted(array)
        
        if array == sorted_array:
            results.append((0, []))
            continue
        
        actions = []
        
        # A simple strategy to sort the array using cyclic shifts
        for j in range(n):
            if array[j] != sorted_array[j]:
                # Find the correct position of the current element
                correct_pos = array.index(sorted_array[j], j)
                
                # Perform a cyclic shift to move the element to its correct position
                if correct_pos > j:
                    d = correct_pos - j
                    actions.append((j + 1, correct_pos + 1, d))
                    array[j:correct_pos + 1] = array[j + d:correct_pos + 1] + array[j:j + d]
        
        results.append((len(actions), actions))
    
    return results

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    index = 0
    t = int(data[index])
    index += 1
    test_cases = []
    
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(data[index])
        index += 1
        array = list(map(int, data[index:index + n]))
        index += n
        test_cases.append((n, array))
    
    results = cyclic_shift_sort(t, test_cases)
    
    for k, actions in results:
        print(k)
        for l, r, d in actions:
            print(l, r, d)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

main()

def cyclic_shift_sort(t, test_cases):
    results = []
    
    for n, array in test_cases:
        sorted_array = sorted(array)
        actions = []
        
        if array == sorted_array:
            results.append((0, actions))
            continue
        
        # A simple strategy to sort the array using cyclic shifts
        for i in range(n):
            if array[i] != sorted_array[i]:
                # Find the position of the element that should be here
                target_index = array.index(sorted_array[i], i)
                
                # Perform a cyclic shift to bring the element to the correct position
                if target_index > i:
                    actions.append((i + 1, target_index + 1, target_index - i))
                    segment = array[i:target_index + 1]
                    offset = target_index - i
                    shifted_segment = segment[offset:] + segment[:offset]
                    array[i:target_index + 1] = shifted_segment
        
        results.append((len(actions), actions))
    
    return results

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().strip().split('\n')
    
    t = int(data[0])
    test_cases = []
    index = 1
    
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(data[index])
        array = list(map(int, data[index + 1].split()))
        test_cases.append((n, array))
        index += 2
    
    results = cyclic_shift_sort(t, test_cases)
    
    for k, actions in results:
        print(k)
        for l, r, d in actions:
            print(l, r, d)

if __name__ == "__main__":

main()

def cyclic_shift(arr, l, r, d):
    # Perform a cyclic shift to the left by d on the segment arr[l:r+1]
    segment = arr[l:r+1]
    d = d % len(segment)  # Ensure d is within the bounds of the segment length
    shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
    arr[l:r+1] = shifted_segment

def solve():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    index = 0
    t = int(data[index])
    index += 1
    results = []
    
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(data[index])
        index += 1
        a = list(map(int, data[index:index+n]))
        index += n
        
        sorted_a = sorted(a)
        
        if a == sorted_a:
            results.append("0")
            continue
        
        actions = []
        
        # A simple strategy to sort the array using cyclic shifts
        for i in range(n):
            if a[i] != sorted_a[i]:
                # Find the position of the correct element
                correct_pos = a.index(sorted_a[i], i)
                if correct_pos != i:
                    # Perform a cyclic shift to bring the correct element to position i
                    l = i
                    r = correct_pos
                    d = 1
                    cyclic_shift(a, l, r, d)
                    actions.append(f"{l+1} {r+1} {d}")
        
        results.append(str(len(actions)))
        results.extend(actions)
    
    print("\n".join(results))

if __name__ == "__main__":
    solve()

main()

def cyclic_shift_sort(t, test_cases):
    results = []
    
    for i in range(t):
        n, a = test_cases[i]
        sorted_a = sorted(a)
        
        if a == sorted_a:
            results.append((0, []))
            continue
        
        actions = []
        
        # Simple strategy: repeatedly find the largest unsorted segment and sort it
        for j in range(n):
            if a[j:] != sorted_a[j:]:
                # Find the largest unsorted segment
                l = j + 1
                r = n
                d = 1
                
                # Perform a cyclic shift
                segment = a[l-1:r]
                shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
                a[l-1:r] = shifted_segment
                
                actions.append((l, r, d))
                
                if a == sorted_a:
                    break
        
        results.append((len(actions), actions))
    
    return results

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    index = 0
    t = int(data[index])
    index += 1
    
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(data[index])
        index += 1
        a = list(map(int, data[index:index+n]))
        index += n
        test_cases.append((n, a))
    
    results = cyclic_shift_sort(t, test_cases)
    
    for k, actions in results:
        print(k)
        for l, r, d in actions:
            print(l, r, d)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

main()

def parse_input():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().strip().split('\n')
    
    t = int(data[0])
    test_cases = []
    index = 1
    
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(data[index])
        array = list(map(int, data[index + 1].split()))
        test_cases.append((n, array))
        index += 2
    
    return test_cases

def cyclic_shift(array, l, r, d):
    segment = array[l-1:r]
    d = d % len(segment)  # Ensure d is within the segment length
    shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
    return array[:l-1] + shifted_segment + array[r:]

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(n, array):
    actions = []
    sorted_array = sorted(array)
    
    for i in range(n):
        if array[i] != sorted_array[i]:
            # Find the position of the correct element in the unsorted array
            correct_pos = array.index(sorted_array[i], i)
            # Perform a cyclic shift to bring the correct element to the current position
            if correct_pos > i:
                actions.append((i + 1, correct_pos + 1, correct_pos - i))
                array = cyclic_shift(array, i + 1, correct_pos + 1, correct_pos - i)
    
    return actions

def main():
    test_cases = parse_input()
    results = []
    
    for n, array in test_cases:
        actions = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(n, array)
        results.append((len(actions), actions))
    
    for k, actions in results:
        print(k)
        for l, r, d in actions:
            print(l, r, d)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

main()

def cyclic_shift(arr, l, r, d):
    # Perform a cyclic shift to the left by d on the segment arr[l:r+1]
    segment = arr[l:r+1]
    d = d % len(segment)  # Ensure d is within the bounds of the segment length
    shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
    return arr[:l] + shifted_segment + arr[r+1:]

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(n, arr):
    operations = []
    sorted_arr = sorted(arr)
    
    if arr == sorted_arr:
        return operations  # Already sorted, no operations needed
    
    # A simple strategy to sort the array using cyclic shifts
    for i in range(n):
        if arr[i] != sorted_arr[i]:
            # Find the correct position of arr[i] in the sorted array
            correct_pos = sorted_arr.index(arr[i], i)
            if correct_pos != i:
                # Perform a cyclic shift to move arr[i] to its correct position
                l = i
                r = correct_pos
                d = correct_pos - i  # Shift by the distance to the correct position
                arr = cyclic_shift(arr, l, r, d)
                operations.append((l + 1, r + 1, d))
    
    return operations

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    index = 0
    t = int(data[index])
    index += 1
    results = []
    
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(data[index])
        index += 1
        arr = list(map(int, data[index:index + n]))
        index += n
        
        operations = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(n, arr)
        results.append((len(operations), operations))
    
    for result in results:
        k, operations = result
        print(k)
        for op in operations:
            print(f"{op[0]} {op[1]} {op[2]}")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

main()

def cyclic_shift(arr, l, r, d):
    """Perform a cyclic shift on the segment of the array from l to r by d positions to the left."""
    segment = arr[l:r+1]
    d = d % len(segment)  # Ensure the offset is within the segment length
    shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
    return arr[:l] + shifted_segment + arr[r+1:]

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(n, arr):
    """Sort the array using cyclic shifts and return the list of actions."""
    actions = []
    sorted_arr = sorted(arr)
    
    for i in range(n):
        if arr == sorted_arr:
            break
        # Find the first element that is out of place
        for j in range(n):
            if arr[j] != sorted_arr[j]:
                break
        # Find the correct position of this element
        correct_pos = arr.index(sorted_arr[j], j)
        # Perform a cyclic shift to move the element to its correct position
        if j < correct_pos:
            d = correct_pos - j
            arr = cyclic_shift(arr, j, correct_pos, d)
            actions.append((j + 1, correct_pos + 1, d))
    
    return actions

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().splitlines()
    
    t = int(data[0])
    index = 1
    results = []
    
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(data[index])
        arr = list(map(int, data[index + 1].split()))
        index += 2
        
        actions = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(n, arr)
        results.append((len(actions), actions))
    
    for k, actions in results:
        print(k)
        for l, r, d in actions:
            print(l, r, d)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

main()

def parse_input():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().strip().split('\n')
    
    t = int(data[0])
    test_cases = []
    index = 1
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(data[index])
        array = list(map(int, data[index + 1].split()))
        test_cases.append((n, array))
        index += 2
    return test_cases

def cyclic_shift(arr, l, r, d):
    # Perform a cyclic shift to the left by d on the segment arr[l:r+1]
    segment = arr[l:r+1]
    d = d % len(segment)  # Ensure d is within the bounds of the segment length
    shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
    return arr[:l] + shifted_segment + arr[r+1:]

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(n, array):
    actions = []
    sorted_array = sorted(array)
    
    if array == sorted_array:
        return actions
    
    # A simple strategy: bubble sort-like approach using cyclic shifts
    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(n - 1, i, -1):
            if array[j] < array[j - 1]:
                # Perform a cyclic shift to swap array[j] and array[j-1]
                array = cyclic_shift(array, j - 1, j, 1)
                actions.append((j, j + 1, 1))
    
    return actions

def main():
    test_cases = parse_input()
    results = []
    
    for n, array in test_cases:
        actions = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(n, array)
        results.append((len(actions), actions))
    
    for k, actions in results:
        print(k)
        for l, r, d in actions:
            print(l, r, d)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

main()

def cyclic_shift_sort(test_cases):
    results = []
    
    for n, array in test_cases:
        sorted_array = sorted(array)
        actions = []
        
        if array == sorted_array:
            results.append((0, []))
            continue
        
        # A simple strategy to sort the array using cyclic shifts
        for i in range(n):
            if array[i] != sorted_array[i]:
                # Find the correct position of the current element
                correct_pos = array.index(sorted_array[i], i)
                
                # Perform a cyclic shift to move the element to its correct position
                if correct_pos > i:
                    d = correct_pos - i
                    actions.append((i + 1, correct_pos + 1, d))
                    array[i:correct_pos + 1] = array[i + d:correct_pos + 1] + array[i:i + d]
        
        results.append((len(actions), actions))
    
    return results

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    index = 0
    t = int(data[index])
    index += 1
    test_cases = []
    
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(data[index])
        index += 1

    for k, actions in results:

        for l, r, d in actions:
            print(l, r, d)

if __name__ == "__main__":

main()

def cyclic_shift_sort(t, test_cases):
    results = []
    
    for i in range(t):
        n, a = test_cases[i]
        sorted_a = sorted(a)
        
        if a == sorted_a:
            results.append((0, []))
            continue
        
        actions = []
        
        # A simple strategy to sort the array using cyclic shifts
        for j in range(n):
            if a[j] != sorted_a[j]:
                # Find the correct position of a[j] in the sorted array
                correct_pos = sorted_a.index(a[j])
                
                # We need to shift the segment [j, correct_pos] to the left
                if j < correct_pos:
                    l = j + 1
                    r = correct_pos + 1
                    d = correct_pos - j
                    actions.append((l, r, d))
                    
                    # Perform the shift
                    segment = a[l-1:r]
                    a[l-1:r] = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
        
        results.append((len(actions), actions))
    
    return results

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    index = 0
    t = int(data[index])
    index += 1
    
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(data[index])
        index += 1
        a = list(map(int, data[index:index + n]))
        index += n
        test_cases.append((n, a))
    
    results = cyclic_shift_sort(t, test_cases)
    
    for k, actions in results:
        print(k)
        for l, r, d in actions:
            print(l, r, d)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

        results.append((len(actions), actions))
    
    return results

def cyclic_shift(arr, l, r, d):
    # Perform a cyclic shift to the left by d on the segment arr[l:r+1]
    segment = arr[l:r+1]
    d = d % len(segment)  # Ensure d is within the bounds of the segment length
    shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
    arr[l:r+1] = shifted_segment

def solve():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    index = 0
    t = int(data[index])
    index += 1
    results = []
    
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(data[index])
        index += 1
        a = list(map(int, data[index:index+n]))
        index += n
        
        sorted_a = sorted(a)
        
        if a == sorted_a:
            results.append("0")
            continue
        
        actions = []
        
        # A simple strategy to sort the array using cyclic shifts
        for i in range(n):
            if a[i] != sorted_a[i]:
                # Find the position of the correct element
                correct_pos = a.index(sorted_a[i], i)
                if correct_pos != i:
                    # Perform a cyclic shift to bring the correct element to position i
                    l = i
                    r = correct_pos
                    d = 1
                    cyclic_shift(a, l, r, d)
                    actions.append(f"{l+1} {r+1} {d}")
        
        results.append(str(len(actions)))
        results.extend(actions)
    
    print("\n".join(results))

if __name__ == "__main__":
    solve()

def cyclic_shift_sort(t, test_cases):
    results = []
    
    for i in range(t):
        n, a = test_cases[i]
        sorted_a = sorted(a)
        
        if a == sorted_a:
            results.append((0, []))
            continue
        
        actions = []
        
        # Simple strategy: repeatedly find the largest unsorted segment and sort it
        for j in range(n):
            if a[j:] != sorted_a[j:]:
                # Find the largest unsorted segment
                l = j + 1
                r = n
                d = 1
                
                # Perform a cyclic shift
                segment = a[l-1:r]
                shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
                a[l-1:r] = shifted_segment
                
                actions.append((l, r, d))
                
                if a == sorted_a:
                    break
        
        results.append((len(actions), actions))
    
    return results

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    index = 0
    t = int(data[index])
    index += 1
    
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(data[index])
        index += 1
        a = list(map(int, data[index:index+n]))
        index += n
        test_cases.append((n, a))
    
    results = cyclic_shift_sort(t, test_cases)
    
    for k, actions in results:
        print(k)
        for l, r, d in actions:
            print(l, r, d)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

def parse_input():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().strip().split('\n')
    
    t = int(data[0])
    test_cases = []
    index = 1
    
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(data[index])
        array = list(map(int, data[index + 1].split()))
        test_cases.append((n, array))
        index += 2
    
    return test_cases

def cyclic_shift(array, l, r, d):
    segment = array[l-1:r]
    d = d % len(segment)  # Ensure d is within the segment length
    shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
    return array[:l-1] + shifted_segment + array[r:]

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(n, array):
    actions = []
    sorted_array = sorted(array)
    
    for i in range(n):
        if array[i] != sorted_array[i]:
            # Find the position of the correct element in the unsorted array
            correct_pos = array.index(sorted_array[i], i)
            # Perform a cyclic shift to bring the correct element to the current position
            if correct_pos > i:
                actions.append((i + 1, correct_pos + 1, correct_pos - i))
                array = cyclic_shift(array, i + 1, correct_pos + 1, correct_pos - i)
    
    return actions

def main():
    test_cases = parse_input()
    results = []
    
    for n, array in test_cases:
        actions = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(n, array)
        results.append((len(actions), actions))
    
    for k, actions in results:
        print(k)
        for l, r, d in actions:
            print(l, r, d)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

def cyclic_shift(arr, l, r, d):
    # Perform a cyclic shift to the left by d on the segment arr[l:r+1]
    segment = arr[l:r+1]
    d = d % len(segment)  # Ensure d is within the bounds of the segment length
    shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
    return arr[:l] + shifted_segment + arr[r+1:]

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(n, arr):
    operations = []
    sorted_arr = sorted(arr)
    
    if arr == sorted_arr:
        return operations  # Already sorted, no operations needed
    
    # A simple strategy to sort the array using cyclic shifts
    for i in range(n):
        if arr[i] != sorted_arr[i]:
            # Find the correct position of arr[i] in the sorted array
            correct_pos = sorted_arr.index(arr[i], i)
            if correct_pos != i:
                # Perform a cyclic shift to move arr[i] to its correct position
                l = i
                r = correct_pos
                d = 1  # Shift by 1 to the left
                arr = cyclic_shift(arr, l, r, d)
                operations.append((l + 1, r + 1, d))
    
    return operations

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    index = 0
    t = int(data[index])
    index += 1
    results = []
    
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(data[index])
        index += 1
        arr = list(map(int, data[index:index + n]))
        index += n
        
        operations = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(n, arr)
        results.append((len(operations), operations))

def cyclic_shift(arr, l, r, d):
    """Perform a cyclic shift on the segment of the array from l to r by d positions to the left."""
    segment = arr[l:r+1]
    d = d % len(segment)  # Ensure the offset is within the segment length
    shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
    return arr[:l] + shifted_segment + arr[r+1:]

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(n, arr):
    """Sort the array using cyclic shifts and return the list of actions."""
    actions = []
    sorted_arr = sorted(arr)
    
    for i in range(n):
        if arr == sorted_arr:
            break
        # Find the first element that is out of place
        for j in range(n):
            if arr[j] != sorted_arr[j]:
                break
        # Find the correct position of this element
        correct_pos = arr.index(sorted_arr[j], j)
        # Perform a cyclic shift to move the element to its correct position
        if j < correct_pos:
            d = correct_pos - j
            arr = cyclic_shift(arr, j, correct_pos, d)
            actions.append((j + 1, correct_pos + 1, d))
    
    return actions

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().splitlines()
    
    t = int(data[0])
    index = 1
    results = []
    
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(data[index])
        arr = list(map(int, data[index + 1].split()))
        index += 2
        
        actions = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(n, arr)
        results.append((len(actions), actions))
    
    for k, actions in results:
        print(k)
        for l, r, d in actions:
            print(l, r, d)

if __name__ == "__main__":

def parse_input():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().strip().split('\n')
    
    t = int(data[0])
    test_cases = []
    index = 1
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(data[index])
        array = list(map(int, data[index + 1].split()))
        test_cases.append((n, array))
        index += 2
    return test_cases

def cyclic_shift(arr, l, r, d):
    # Perform a cyclic shift to the left by d on the segment arr[l:r+1]
    segment = arr[l:r+1]
    d = d % len(segment)  # Ensure d is within the bounds of the segment length
    shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
    return arr[:l] + shifted_segment + arr[r+1:]

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(n, array):
    actions = []
    sorted_array = sorted(array)
    
    if array == sorted_array:
        return actions
    
    # A simple strategy: bubble sort-like approach using cyclic shifts
    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(n - 1, i, -1):
            if array[j] < array[j - 1]:
                # Perform a cyclic shift to swap array[j] and array[j-1]
                array = cyclic_shift(array, j - 1, j, 1)
                actions.append((j, j + 1, 1))
    
    return actions

def main():
    test_cases = parse_input()
    results = []
    
    for n, array in test_cases:
        actions = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(n, array)
        results.append((len(actions), actions))
    
    for k, actions in results:
        print(k)
        for l, r, d in actions:
            print(l, r, d)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

                    segment = a[l-1:r]
                    a[l-1:r] = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
        
        results.append((len(actions), actions))
    
    return results

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    index = 0
    t = int(data[index])
    index += 1
    
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(data[index])
        index += 1
        a = list(map(int, data[index:index + n]))
        index += n
        test_cases.append((n, a))
    
    results = cyclic_shift_sort(t, test_cases)
    
    for k, actions in results:
        print(k)
        for l, r, d in actions:
            print(l, r, d)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

Round_0.code:
def cyclic_shift_sort(t, test_cases):
    results = []
    
    for i in range(t):
        n, array = test_cases[i]
        sorted_array = sorted(array)
        
        if array == sorted_array:
            results.append((0, []))
            continue
        
        actions = []
        
        # A simple strategy to sort the array using cyclic shifts
        for j in range(n):
            if array[j] != sorted_array[j]:
                # Find the correct position of the current element
                correct_pos = array.index(sorted_array[j], j)
                
                # Perform a cyclic shift to move the element to its correct position
                if correct_pos > j:
                    d = correct_pos - j
                    actions.append((j + 1, correct_pos + 1, d))
                    array[j:correct_pos + 1] = array[j + d:correct_pos + 1] + array[j:j + d]
        
        results.append((len(actions), actions))
    
    return results

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    index = 0
    t = int(data[index])
    index += 1
    test_cases = []
    
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(data[index])
        index += 1
        array = list(map(int, data[index:index + n]))
        index += n
        test_cases.append((n, array))
    
    results = cyclic_shift_sort(t, test_cases)
    
    for k, actions in results:
        print(k)
        for l, r, d in actions:
            print(l, r, d)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

prompt:
The new generation external memory comprises an array of integers a[1 … n] = [a_1, a_2, …, a_n].

This type of memory does not support changing the value of an arbitrary element. Instead, it allows you to cut out any segment of the given array, cyclically shift (rotate) it by any offset and insert it back into the same place.

Technically, each cyclic shift consists of two consecutive actions: 

  1. You may select arbitrary indices l and r (1 ≤ l < r ≤ n) as the boundaries of the segment. 
  2. Then you substitute the segment a[l … r] with its cyclic shift to the left by an arbitrary offset d. The concept of a cyclic shift can be also explained by following relations: the sequence [1, 4, 1, 3] is a cyclic shift of the sequence [3, 1, 4, 1] to the left by the offset 1 and the sequence [4, 1, 3, 1] is a cyclic shift of the sequence [3, 1, 4, 1] to the left by the offset 2. 

For example, if a = [1, \color{blue}{3, 2, 8}, 5], then choosing l = 2, r = 4 and d = 2 yields a segment a[2 … 4] = [3, 2, 8]. This segment is then shifted by the offset d = 2 to the left, and you get a segment [8, 3, 2] which then takes the place of of the original elements of the segment. In the end you get a = [1, \color{blue}{8, 3, 2}, 5].

Arrange the given array a in order using no more than n cyclic shifts of any of its parts. Note that you don't need to minimize the number of cyclic shifts. Any method that requires n or less cyclic shifts will be accepted.

Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of test cases.

The next 2t lines contain the descriptions of the test cases. 

The first line of each test case description contains an integer n (2 ≤ n ≤ 50) — the length of the array. The second line consists of space-separated elements of the array a_i (-10^9 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^9). Elements of array a may repeat and don't have to be unique.

Output

Print t answers to all input test cases. 

The first line of the answer of each test case should contain an integer k (0 ≤ k ≤ n) — the number of actions to sort the array. The next k lines should contain descriptions of the actions formatted as "l r d" (without quotes) where l and r (1 ≤ l < r ≤ n) are the boundaries of the segment being shifted, while d (1 ≤ d ≤ r - l) is the offset value. Please remember that only the cyclic shifts to the left are considered so the chosen segment will be shifted by the offset d to the to the left.

Note that you are not required to find the minimum number of cyclic shifts needed for sorting. Any sorting method where the number of shifts does not exceed n will be accepted.

If the given array a is already sorted, one of the possible answers is k = 0 and an empty sequence of cyclic shifts.

If there are several possible answers, you may print any of them.

Example

Input


4
2
2 1
3
1 2 1
4
2 4 1 3
5
2 5 1 4 3


Output


1
1 2 1
1
1 3 2
3
2 4 1
2 3 1
1 3 2
4
2 4 2
1 5 3
1 2 1
1 3 1

Note

Explanation of the fourth data set in the example: 

  1. The segment a[2 … 4] is selected and is shifted to the left by 2: [2, \color{blue}{5, 1, 4}, 3] \longrightarrow [2, \color{blue}{4, 5, 1}, 3] 
  2. The segment a[1 … 5] is then selected and is shifted to the left by 3: [\color{blue}{2, 4, 5, 1, 3}] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 3, 2, 4, 5}] 
  3. After that the segment a[1 … 2] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{1, 3}, 2, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{3, 1}, 2, 4, 5] 
  4. And in the end the segment a[1 … 3] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{3, 1, 2}, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 2, 3}, 4, 5]
